title: No. 18 Hornets ready for test against No. 13 Gorillas
text:
No. 18 Hornets ready for test against No. 13 Gorillas Emporia State looking to continue unbeaten season Posted: October 8, 2015 - 3:18pm By Rick Peterson Jr. richard.peterson@cjonline.com 
After suffering an upset loss to Washburn in the third week of the season, Pittsburg State came dangerously close the last two weeks to taking another loss and seeing its playoff hopes take a huge hit. 
Instead, the No. 13-ranked Gorillas rallied twice to stay in the national conversation, setting up a top-20 clash with No. 18 Emporia State at 2 p.m. Saturday in Welch Stadium. 
Pittsburg State (4-1) pulled out a 31-24 win at Fort Hays State after trailing by 10 at halftime, and then wiped out a 17-point halftime deficit against Missouri Western to edge the Griffons 31-27. 
“The thing that stands out to me, is they’ve had their backs against the wall, and they’ve been able to show resiliency in being able to come back and fight and get wins the last two weeks,” ESU coach Garin Higgins said. “That’s impressive how they’ve had to battle back and how they just kept playing. 
“They play very hard on both sides of the football, and they’re a very good football team. There’s a reason why they’re ranked. There’s a reason why they have a culture there that’s a championship culture. We’re looking forward to the challenge.” 
Emporia State enters 5-0 after remaining perfect with a 20-13 win over Lindenwood last week. 
Pittsburg State ranks third in the conference in total offense at 452.4 yards per game and is sixth in total defense, allowing 393.6 yards a game. 
PSU freshman quarterback John Roderique is leading the MIAA in rushing touchdowns with seven. Gorillas defensive back Darnell Walker has a league-high five interceptions. 
“I would say the biggest thing for us is to make sure we take care of the ball and don’t let the pressure get to you,” ESU receiver Mitchell Foote said. “That’s a powerhouse team coming in here to your stadium. Being 5-0 doesn’t mean anything, so you can’t let that get to you.” 
ESU quarterback Brent Wilson agreed. 
“Pitt State is arguably one of the greatest football powerhouses in the nation year in and year out, but it’s a typical game for us,” he said. “We’re not going to change anything special or do anything that we’re not capable of doing. 
“We just have to stay together and not let the emotions get the best of us.” MIAA GAMES SATURDAY 
Central Missouri at Washburn, 2:37 p.m. 
Pittsburg State at Emporia, 2 p.m. 
Fort Hays State at Missouri Western, 1 p.m. 
Lindenwood at Northwest Missouri, 1 p.m. 
Northeastern State at Nebraska-Kearney, 2 p.m. 
Central Oklahoma at Missouri Southern, 6 p.m.
